paper_name: Shared structural mechanisms of general anaesthetics and benzodiazepines

pockets.description: The relatively high disorder in the γ-TMD observed in all structures was most notable in the flumazenil complex, in which a gap is present at the γ–β interface. This gap shrinks in the absence of flumazenil and disappears in the presence of diazepam.

In vitro mutagenesis studies identified binding sites for both compounds at the β–α interfaces, in positions equivalent to the β–α TMD binding sites of diazepam; these binding sites were responsible for the potentiation of GABA binding by these compounds, as well as for the direct activation of the receptor at higher concentrations.

The binding mode of phenobarbital is equivalent for the two sites: the barbituric acid group rests deep in the M3–M1 interfaces, the phenyl group orients away from the channel axis and the ethyl group orients towards the pore.
